I face this issue with someone in our community who has an autistic family member, and who is also an amazing individual who does great things for our schools. They ask the kids to bring in little donations for autism and those donations go to Autism Speaks, an organization I do not support for the reasons elaborated in this article.

I have a very hard time denying my kid the right to earn the donation, or using this cause in particular as a case for "be aware of charities" because I feel in this case, preaching will not change the behavior of the community member in question. I also think that it would undermine their credibility unfairly. Finally, as someone who does not have an autistic child, I simply do not believe it's my place to tell those parents about autism, even if I think they are wrong.

If you think giving up ice-cream is hard, imagine giving up the trust of someone in your community whom you respect and want to support.

It is a very difficult situation indeed because they are like a fundraising supernova.

As an autistic who vehemently prefers 'autistic [person]' to 'person with autism', and in fact strongly dislikes the latter (though some of us do prefer that designation for their own reasons): I appreciate your kind intent, but I'm afraid your argument has several grave flaws and presents an implication I find disturbing.

I am autistic. I am autistic just like I am brown-haired and short and Canadian. It's an adjective that describes me just the same way as any of those words, and constructions like 'brown-haired person' or 'brunette' do not at all imply that I am solely defined by any of the above characteristics.

Yet, no one in my life so far has ever chided me for failing to refer to myself as a 'person with brown eyes' or a 'person with shortness' or a 'person with Canadianness'. Why not? What is specific to my autism -- which DOES define me, IS a part of me, if not the entirety thereof -- that prompts anyone to state that the use of 'person-first language' is imperative? Why is denying my humanity suddenly a concern when it comes to that particular descriptive phrase, 'autistic'? Do you feel that to call someone autistic is to insult them? If so, please do ask yourself why that is.

Why should you (general 'you'; I do not mean to make any accusations regarding your own thoughts) make that sort of exception? More to the point: why would you diminish the fact of my autism in the name of affirming my humanity unless you thought precisely that my autism dehumanizes me?

If you are happy with the way you are, then there is no point in taking them but saying that autism speaks is a bad organization because they want to find a cure or treatment means that those severely affected will never have a chance to live independently.

My kids are 8 and almost 11 and I've yet to come across a form that didn't come with instructions -- or with supplemental instructions on the camp (or whatever activity's) website.

I absolutely agree that many of the forms are annoying and redundant -- and some of the requirements (physical must be within past X days or whatever) make no sense. However, if you want your kid to go to that camp, you WILL completing all those forms to the camp's (very possibly stupid) standards.

Your options really are limited to Do It Exactly the Way Camp X Wants It Done or re-do it until you've done it Camp X's way. The former is much, much easier.

***

It's certainly possible that there are camps with confusing forms and no supplementary information on their websites -- in which case, a parent has cutting edge tools like phones and access to e-mail that can be used to seek clarification from the camp. Why not avail yourself of them?

I can also appreciate that everyone on the Autism Spectrum may not and do not have the same wants, desires, challenges and gifts.  Not all people with ASD have the ability to fight for themself.  Not all people with ASD have a voice.  Not all people with ASD can have the conversation we are having.  I oppose hate speak on any level. Some people with ASD are very low functioning and require constant support - support that makes them vulunerable to abuse and neglect from anyone.  If a person with ASD is happy and living their life the way they want to, that is a wonderful success.  A person with ASD can have an IQ of 10 or 110.  Those with higher IQ's and have a voice, I ask you to share your experiences with social interaction, sensory integration, speech and language, sadness, pain, expression so that those with lower functioning autism may have a voice. Banty - I am aware that African-American hair requires different styles/products than Caucasian hair AND that a Caucasian parent may well have a steep learning curve in learning to care for African-American hair.

It's still totally inappropriate for a total stranger to approach a mom/dad and offer unsolicited hair-care advice. It's rude. It's presumptuous. It's unlikely to be helpful OR well-received.

So, probably most kids, probably most people, will take advantage of some kind of medical treatment or therapy or intervention in the course of their lives to improve the quality of their life or help overcome some specific impairment. Glasses. Braces. Speech therapy. Physical therapy. Surgery for issues that may shorten a child's lifespan.

But when we do those things to help most people, we're not talking about changing them into a different kind of person.

Autism is not just impairment. Autism is *how* our brains work. It's our basic neurological configuration. It has strengths, and it has drawbacks, just like being non-autistic does. (Think being non-autistic doesn't have drawbacks? Do y'all have any idea how much your pattern recognition abilities suck? Well, they suck bad. You can barely hear compared to me, and let's not even start on the deficiency of your long term memories. Okay, moving on.)

When we address specific deficiencies most of the time, we're not talking about trying to erase and over-write a child's basic neurological configuration.

That's what curing autism would do, by necessity. That's what it would entail. To truly cure autism, all of it, would rob us of everything good and strong and wonderful about the way we work, neurologically, as well as everything wrong and hard.

Non-autistic people don't tend to know how to see the good stuff. We experience it, though. And we'd lose that, too, with a cure.

Non-disabled people have assumed since time-immemorial that disabled people want to be cured. That's based on two things, the arrogant assumption that their life is superior to ours, and never bothering to ask us what we think.

We've given up waiting to be asked what we think, nowadays we'll tell you. That a disabled life is fully as valid as yours and that for many of us we have no desire whatsoever for a cure. And that refusing to listen to us is more than wrongheaded, it's actively discriminatory.

" it seems just plain cruel to deny the blind, deaf, physically and intellectually disabled and autistic the chance to become sighted, hearing, able-bodied, educated or socially interactive if they want to and have the chance"

Have you asked us? There are huge numbers of disabled people who don't want to be cured. I'm one, and it's a commonly held position among the neurodiverse community.

"but to accord such disability the status of something in which to take pride"

A principle of disability rights is that being disabled in no way makes you a lesser person. That means that disability is not viewed as a negative. And one way of countering negative opinions directed at us (which can go all the way up to being assaulted in the street), is to express pride in our status as disabled people. So yes, not only do we have pride in our disabilities, we have disability pride marches.

"lesser person"?  Having inferiority in functionality/fortune is completely different from being morally/spiritually inferior.  We don't have the same chances and potential in life, even while being morally equal individuals.  Disability is a tremendous negative and you know that.  Disability pride?  That's downright shameful.  I as a neurologically disabled person loathe such tendencies in this society.

A  disability, while abled individuals should accept and accommodate those who have it, is NOT the same thing as a gender, height, race, color, ethnicity, age or a feature.  Except for transgender individuals, one’s gender isn’t something to be “corrected,” nor is one’s race, sexual orientation, ethnicity, age, etc.  But it seems just plain cruel to deny the blind, deaf, physically and intellectually disabled and autistic the chance to become sighted, hearing, able-bodied, educated or socially interactive if they want to and have the chance.  It’s one thing for people with a particular disability or disorder to seek out affinity groups with others similarly situated--but to accord such disability the status of something in which to take pride (and feel superior to the able-bodied-and minded) is simply wrongheaded.

It's a human thing. Granted, most shampoo ads are geared toward women, but with all the hair color and hair loss products for men, it's not even the gender issue it once was. Otherwise, we wouldn't see so many men with combovers.

@Jake -- I named two "disabilities" that do not necessarily require a "cure" in my comment:  generalized anxiety, and panic in crowds.  Many people don't get treatment for these "abnormal" conditions, and do just fine. On the other hand, lots of people get therapy for "adjustment difficulties", or just to help in areas where they feel they are below the curve.  As to "normal", it has a pretty specific technical meaning, as in "norm".  Few of us are at the norm on every measure, but we manage to function.  The same is true of many people with autism.
